citation.article-title: Isolation and characterization of an anaerobic cellulolytic microorganism, Acetivibrio cellulolyticus gen. nov., sp. nov.

p.s: Acetivibrio (L. noun acetum, vinegar; M.L. mas. n. Vibrio genus of bacteria, vibrio; M.L. mas. n. acetivibrio, vinegar (acetic) vibrio)
Morphology: straight to slightly curved rods measuring 4 to 10 by 0.5 to 0.8 μm.
Chains of cells up to 40 μm in length also occur.
Gram-negative, monotrichous cells which exhibit tumbling motility.
The flagellum is attached to the cell about one-third of the distance from pole to pole.
Colony characteristics: cream-colored, round, 1 to 2 mm in diameter, raised, with an undulate margin.
A zone of cellulose digestion extending from the periphery of the colony is observed in cellulose agar.
DNA base composition: 38 mol% G + C.
pH relationships: optimum, around 7.0; minimum and maximum, around 6.5 and 7.7, respectively.
Temperature relationships: Optimum, around 35°C; minimum and maximum, 20 and 40°C, respectively.
Physiology: obligately anaerobic; cellulose, cellobiose, and salicin serve as growth substrates.
This strain has been deposited in the National Research Council (NRC) of Canada culture collection under the accession number 2248.
Source: Methanogenic enrichment culture from sewage sludge.
